page.title: 16KENLEY WATERWORKS & CHALK
page.content: { KENLEY WATERWORKS AND CHALK PLANT The water is pumped from chalk below the Water table.The Works are 91 years old,built in 1894.It is now computerized ,with each of the 5 bore holes having its own computer.Three men are needed to run it working on an eight hour shift 24 hours a day.On average 30 men are employed there. About 3,000,000 gallons of water is pumped up per day,supplying Kenley, Whyteleafe and Warlingham on its way to Warlingham Reservoir.The water is pumped from 100m into softening tanks where it is treated with chlorine and amonia.Quick lime is added to the water,and then it is left for five hours to settle.The chalk that is produced is dried in the chalk plant, placed in sacks and sent all over the world.
